properties.name: 19/19a Tavistock Square
properties.description: Posted by Londonbahais19/19a Tavistock Square, WC1 Formerly the Theosophical Society (now demolished) where \'Abdu\'l-Baha spoke on Thursday 30 September 1911. He spoke there again on Friday 3 Janaury 1913 when His subject was \'The Spiritual Force\'.

properties.name: 2-8 Victoria Street, SW1
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisLondonFormerly the Westminster Palace Hotel where Abdu\'l-Baha addressed His first public audience on His second visit to London on Friday 20 December 1912. Westminster Palace Hotel was rebuilt in 1979 and is now called the Abbey House.

properties.name: 28 Evelyn Mansions
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisCarlyle Place, SW1 The home of Sir William Robinson. Abdu\'l-Baha attended a Nineteen Day Feast here on Sunday 29 December 1912.

properties.name: 3/20/26? Wilton Crescent SW1
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisThe home of Lord Lamington, visited by Abdu\'l-Baha on Christmas Day 1912.

properties.name: 31 Evelyn Mansions
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisCarlyle Place, SW1 Home of Mrs. Thornburgh Cropper (the first person to become a Baha\'i in the UK). Abdu\'l-Baha spoke here on Tuesday 12 September 1911. He returned the following day for a visit. He also spoke here at a meeting on 1 January 1913.

properties.name: 37 Tavistock Place
properties.description: Posted by Londonbahais37 Tavistock Place, WC1 Formerly the Passmore Edwards Settlement. \'Abdu\'l-Baha spoke there on Friday 8 September 1911 and again on Wednesday 29 September 1911 at a farewell meeting arranged by Mrs Thornburgh Cropper for more than 200 guests.

properties.name: Caxton Hall
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisCaxton Hall, Caxton Street SW1 \'Abdu\'l-Baha spoke here on Tuesday 17 December 1912 again on Saturday 11 January 1913.

properties.name: Church House, Westminster
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisGreat Smith Street, SW1 (This building was demolished in the Second World War.) \'Abdu\'l-Baha watched Mary Blomfield acting the main role in \'Eager Heart\' by Alice Buckton on Sunday 22 December 1912.

properties.name: Essex Hall
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisEssex Street, WC2 Abdu\'l-Baha spoke to the Women\'s Freedom League on \'Equality\' on Thursday 2 January 1913. The hall was destroyed in 1944 and rebuilt in 1948. It is the headquarters of the Unitarian and free Christian Churches and stands at the site of the original Unitarian Church established in 1774.

properties.name: Guardian's Resting Place
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisShoghi Effendi\'s Burial Place Shoghi Effendi\'s burial place is located in New Southgate Cemetery & Crematorium. The nearest tube station is Arnos Grove on the Piccadilly Line, which is about a 15 minutes walk or 3 minute cab ride. If you decide to walk, take the short cut into the cemetery (gates close at sunset during winter) via Darwin Close which will take you directly Shoghi Effendi\'s burial place. Remember to pop in to the visitor\'s center and say hello to Mr Alaee.

properties.name: Hyde Park
properties.description: Posted by Londonbahais Abdu\'l-Baha walked on the Serpentine Bridge sometime during His first visit to London. On Wednesday 18 December 1912 He walked in the park and Mrs. Thornburgh Cropper took Him there again in her car on Friday 27 December 1912.

properties.name: Lady Blomfield's Grave
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisHampstead Municipal Cemetery is to be found just off Fortune Green Road as it joins Finchley Road. The nearst Underground station is West Hampstead on the Jubilee Line. Lady Blomfield\'s grave is to be found by entering through the main gates, turning right at the first avenue and then immediately left onto a gravel path running parallel to the main drive. After about 100 yards there is a black marble headstone with the name Helena Narkowicz on it. Enter the section at that point and Lady Blomfield\'s grave is in the sixth line of graves and one grave to the right. The National Spiritual Assembly wishes to record its deep appreciation to Mr David Lewis, Mr Ron Batchelor and Michelle Wilburn for their dedication to and successful completion of this project.

properties.name: Lady Blomfield's Home
properties.description: Posted by Londonbahais\'Abdu\'l-Baha first arrived in London on Monday 4 September 1911. He stayed at the Chelsea home of Lady Blomfield at 97 Cadogan Gardens. The first talk he gave anywhere in the West was at the City Temple in the City of London. He left London on 3 October but returned at the end of the following year for a further stay from 16 December 1912 to 21 January 1913. During \'Abdu\'l-Baha\'s stays he visited a number of different sites in Westminster

properties.name: National Bahá'i Centre
properties.description: Posted by Londonbahais27 Rutland Gate SW7

properties.name: Paddington Station
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisAbdu\'l-Baha departed from Paddington for Bristol Temple Meads on Saturday 23 September 1911 returning two days later. He also used Paddington to visit Oxford on Tuesday 31 December 1912. On Thursday 16 January 1913 He made a second trip to Bristol returning the following day.

properties.name: Royal Albert Hall
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisFirst Bahá\'í World Congress The Royal Albert Hall was the setting for the First Bahá\'í World Congress, from 28 April to 2 May 1963, when over 6,000 Bahá\'ís from all over the globe gathered to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Declaration by Bahá\'u\'lláh of His mission. It was at this gathering that the Universal House of Justice, elected for the first time only days before, was first presented to the Bahá\'ís and where its first message was read.

properties.name: Salvation Army Shelter
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisGreat Peter Street & St. Ann\'s Street, SW1 Abdu\'l-Baha addressed 1000 men at their Christmas dinner on 25 December 1912 and left 20 gold sovereigns for a repeat dinner on New Year\'s Day.

properties.name: Society of Friends
properties.description: Posted by Londonbahais52 St. Martin\'s Lane, WC2 Abdu\'l-Baha spoke to the Society of Friends on the subject of the \'Divine Light and Meditation\' on Sunday 12 January 1913.

properties.name: St. John the Divine
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisSmith Square, SW1 Abdu\'l-Baha visited in the morning of Sunday 17 September 1911 where He addressed the congregation and revealed a prayer. Abdu\'l-Baha at the request of the venerable Archdeacon of Westminster addressed the congregation. With a few warn words the Archdeacon Wilberforce introduced the revered Messenger from the East, who had crossed seas and countries on His mission of Peace and Unity for which He had suffered 40 years of captivity and persecution. The Archdeacon had the Bishop\'s chair placed for his guest on the Chapel steps, and standing beside Him read the translation of Abdu\'l-Baha\'s address himself. The congregation was profoundly moved, and following the Archdeacon\'s example, knelt to receive the blessings of the Servant of God. St. John\'s Church was built in 1721-8 by Thomas Archer and gutted by bombing in 1941. It was carefull restored in 1963-9 and is now used as an art centre for concerts and lectures.

properties.name: The Serpentine
properties.description: Posted by Londonbahais". . . the evening light was waning as we crossed the Serpentine bridge. Rows of shining lamps beneath the trees, stretching as far as our eyes could see into the distance, made that part of London into a glowing fairyland. \'I am very much pleased with this scene, Light is good, most good. There was much darkness in the prison at \'Akká,\' said the Master [ \'Abdu\'l-Bahá]." Lady Blomfield The Chosen Highway p. 166.

properties.name: Victoria Station
properties.description: Posted by LondonbahaisAbdu\'l-Baha left from Victoria on His sea voyage to France on Sunday 3 October 1911. He also finally left London on Tuesday 21 january 1913.

properties.name: Walmar House
properties.description: Posted by Londonbahais296 Regent St, Westminster, London W1B A Baha\'i centre was opened in London in September 1929 at Walmar House, Regent Street. After several temporary moves, a National Baha\'i Centre was purchased in 1954 at 27 Rutland Gate in Knightsbridge, London.
